arm_group.description: Ultrasound scan using acoustic radiation force impulse-shear wave velocity imaging in the characterization of pediatric hydronephrosis. This is a non-invasive scan that uses sound waves to create the images.

brief_summary.textblock:
Pediatric upper urinary tract dilatation (hydronephrosis) is relatively common and may be
      either obstructive or nonobstructive. While the upper urinary tract is commonly evaluated by
      ultrasound, this imaging technique often fails to distinguish obstructed from nonobstructed
      systems.  ARFI SVI is a new ultrasound technology that can be used to determine stiffness by
      measuring a tissue's shear wave velocity, may show alterations in parenchymal shear wave
      velocity in kidneys that show obstruction on DRS (Diuretic renal scintigraphy)which serves
      as the reference standard.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          1. 18 years of age or younger

          2. You are scheduled for diuretic scintigraphy (DRS)testing -

        Exclusion Criteria:

        None

        -

intervention.description: This research scan uses acoustic radiation force impulse (ARFI) shear wave velocity imaging (SVI)a new ultrasound technology in which unique sound waves create the images/pictures of the kidney beng examined/scanned. This ultrasound scan will take approximately 10 minutes to complete.

clinical_study.official_title: Evaluation of Ultrasound Acoustic Radiation Force Impulse (ARFI)Shear Wave Velocity Imaging (SVI)in the Characterization of Pediatric Hydronephrosis

authority: United States: Food and Drug Administration

primary_outcome.description: fibrosis and intratubular pressure will be evidenced by higher parenchymal shear wave velocity measurements using the ARFI-SVI technology.

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.study_design: Endpoint Classification: Safety/Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Single Group Assignment, Masking: Open Label, Primary Purpose: Diagnostic
